question: [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-inspection-service/src/server/peer_information.rs] [Function: handle_peer_information_request()] [Access Control Bypass] Can an attacker bypass the expose_peer_information config check by manipulating the node_config parameter before it reaches line 27, potentially exposing sensitive peer data even when the endpoint should be disabled? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-inspection-service/src/server/peer_information.rs] [Function: handle_peer_information_request()] [Race Condition] Is there a TOCTOU (Time-of-Check-Time-of-Use) race condition between checking node_config.inspection_service.expose_peer_information at line 27 and calling get_peer_information() at line 28, where config could change mid-execution exposing unauthorized data? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-inspection-service/src/server/peer_information.rs] [Function: handle_peer_information_request()] [Information Disclosure] Does the FORBIDDEN status code at line 32 leak information about the node's configuration state, allowing attackers to enumerate which nodes have inspection endpoints enabled for targeted attacks? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-inspection-service/src/server/peer_information.rs] [Function: handle_peer_information_request()] [Input Validation] Are the node_config, aptos_data_client, and peers_and_metadata parameters validated before use at line 21, or can malicious/corrupted inputs cause undefined behavior or information leaks? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-inspection-service/src/server/peer_information.rs] [Function: handle_peer_information_request()] [Response Size DoS] Can an attacker cause the endpoint to generate an unbounded response size by manipulating peer metadata, potentially causing memory exhaustion when get_peer_information() aggregates all peer data at line 28? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-inspection-service/src/server/peer_information.rs] [Function: get_peer_information()] [Arc Shared State Race] Does the Arc<PeersAndMetadata> access at line 43 have proper synchronization, or can concurrent modifications during peer enumeration at lines 46-51 cause inconsistent data exposure or panic? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-inspection-service/src/server/peer_information.rs] [Function: get_peer_information()] [Iterator Exhaustion] Can malicious peers cause get_registered_networks().collect() at line 47 to exhaust memory if an unbounded number of networks are registered, leading to node crash? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-inspection-service/src/server/peer_information.rs] [Function: get_peer_information()] [Sort Algorithm DoS] Does the all_peers.sort() call at line 51 have O(nÂ²) worst-case complexity that could be exploited with adversarially-crafted peer IDs to cause CPU exhaustion during sorting? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-inspection-service/src/server/peer_information.rs] [Function: get_peer_information()] [String Concatenation DoS] Can the join() operation at line 105 cause quadratic string concatenation if peer_information_output contains excessive entries, leading to performance degradation? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-inspection-service/src/server/peer_information.rs] [Function: get_peer_information()] [Information Aggregation Leak] Does aggregating all peer data in lines 54-103 expose sensitive correlation information that could allow attackers to map network topology, identify validator nodes, and plan targeted attacks? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-inspection-service/src/server/peer_information.rs] [Function: get_peer_information()] [Deref Safety] Is the deref() call on peers_and_metadata at lines 66, 74, 82, 94, 102 safe from potential aliasing issues or can it cause undefined behavior if the Arc is dropped elsewhere? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-inspection-service/src/server/peer_information.rs] [Function: get_peer_information()] [Function Call Order Dependency] Do the display functions called in sequence at lines 55-103 have ordering dependencies where calling them out-of-order could expose inconsistent or sensitive state transitions? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-inspection-service/src/server/peer_information.rs] [Function: get_peer_information()] [Vector Growth DoS] Can the Vec<String> peer_information_output grow unbounded if peers contain malicious metadata, causing memory exhaustion before the join() at line 105? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-inspection-service/src/server/peer_information.rs] [Function: display_detailed_monitoring_metadata()] [Debug Format Exposure] Does the {:?} debug formatting at line 121-122 expose sensitive internal state structures or memory addresses that could aid in exploitation or reveal implementation details? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-inspection-service/src/server/peer_information.rs] [Function: display_detailed_monitoring_metadata()] [Error Handling Silent Failure] Does the Ok(peer_metadata) pattern match at line 118 silently skip peers with errors, potentially hiding malicious peer states or allowing selective information disclosure? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-inspection-service/src/server/peer_information.rs] [Function: display_detailed_monitoring_metadata()] [Peer Metadata Tampering] Can a malicious peer inject crafted peer_monitoring_metadata retrieved at line 119 that when formatted at line 121 causes format string vulnerabilities or output injection? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-inspection-service/src/server/peer_information.rs] [Function: display_detailed_monitoring_metadata()] [Loop Termination] Is the for loop at line 117 guaranteed to terminate if all_peers contains circular references or can malicious peer data cause infinite iteration? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-inspection-service/src/server/peer_information.rs] [Function: display_detailed_monitoring_metadata()] [Metadata Access Race] Can get_metadata_for_peer(*peer) at line 118 return stale or inconsistent metadata if peers disconnect/reconnect during iteration, exposing incorrect network state? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-inspection-service/src/server/peer_information.rs] [Function: display_detailed_monitoring_metadata()] [Memory Disclosure] Does get_peer_monitoring_metadata() at line 119 potentially return references to internal memory structures that could leak addresses or heap layout information? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-inspection-service/src/server/peer_information.rs] [Function: display_internal_client_state()] [Critical State Exposure] Does exposing internal_client_state via debug formatting at line 141-142 reveal authentication tokens, private keys, or other secrets that should never be externalized? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-inspection-service/src/server/peer_information.rs] [Function: display_internal_client_state()] [State Machine Disclosure] Can the internal client state at line 142 reveal consensus voting states, proposal statuses, or other state machine information that Byzantine actors could exploit? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-inspection-service/src/server/peer_information.rs] [Function: display_internal_client_state()] [Duplicate Metadata Fetch] Does fetching peer_metadata twice (once for peer_monitoring_metadata at line 139 and implicitly in get_metadata_for_peer) at line 138 create a race window where data inconsistency occurs? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-inspection-service/src/server/peer_information.rs] [Function: display_internal_client_state()] [Timing Side Channel] Does iterating and exposing internal states at lines 137-145 create a timing side channel where response time correlates with internal state complexity, leaking information? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-inspection-service/src/server/peer_information.rs] [Function: display_internal_client_state()] [Field Access Vulnerability] Is the direct field access to internal_client_state at line 142 safe, or could this field contain uninitialized data, null pointers, or invalid states? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-inspection-service/src/server/peer_information.rs] [Function: display_peer_connection_metadata()] [JSON Serialization Panic] Can the serde_json::to_string() call at line 164 panic on malicious connection_metadata structures with circular references, non-serializable types, or deeply nested objects?
